EST	2	19	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17460	" {19} When the virgins were assembled a second time, Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate."
EST	2	20	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17461	" {20} But Esther had kept secret her family background and nationality just as Mordecai had told her to do, for she continued to follow Mordecai's instructions as she had done when he was bringing her up."
EST	2	21	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17462	" {21} During the time Mordecai was sitting at the king's gate, Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king's officers who guarded the doorway, became angry and conspired to assassinate King Xerxes."
EST	2	22	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17463	" {22} But Mordecai found out about the plot and told Queen Esther, who in turn reported it to the king, giving credit to Mordecai."
EST	2	23	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17464	" {23} And when the report was investigated and found to be true, the two officials were hanged on a gallows. "
EST	2	23	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17465	 All this was recorded in the book of the annals in the presence of the king.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
EST	3	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17466	ESTHER 3
EST	3	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17467	" {1} After these events, King Xerxes honored Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, elevating him and giving him a seat of honor higher than that of all the other nobles."
EST	3	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17468	" {2} All the royal officials at the king's gate knelt down and paid honor to Haman, for the king had commanded this concerning him. "
EST	3	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17469	 But Mordecai would not kneel down or pay him honor. {3} Then the royal officials at the king's gate asked Mordecai.
EST	3	3	Official	#13		17470	 << Why do you disobey the king's command?>>
EST	3	4	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17471	" {4} Day after day they spoke to him but he refused to comply. Therefore they told Haman about it to see whether Mordecai's behavior would be tolerated, for he had told them he was a Jew."
EST	3	5	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17472	" {5} When Haman saw that Mordecai would not kneel down or pay him honor, he was enraged."
EST	3	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17473	" {6} Yet having learned who Mordecai's people were, he scorned the idea of killing only Mordecai. "
EST	3	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17474	" Instead Haman looked for a way to destroy all Mordecai's people, the Jews, throughout the whole kingdom of Xerxes."
EST	3	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17475	" {7} In the twelfth year of King Xerxes, in the first month, the month of Nisan, they cast the pur (that is, the lot) in the presence of Haman to select a day and month. "
EST	3	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17476	" And the lot fell on the twelfth month, the month of Adar. {8} Then Haman said to King Xerxes"
EST	3	8	Haman	#11		17477	 << There is a certain people dispersed and scattered among the peoples in all the provinces of your kingdom whose customs are different from those of all other people and who do not obey the king's laws;
EST	3	8	Haman	#11		17478	 it is not in the king's best interest to tolerate them.
EST	3	9	Haman	#11		17479	" {9} If it pleases the king, let a decree be issued to destroy them, and I will put ten thousand talents of silver into the royal treasury for the men who carry out this business.>>"
EST	3	10	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17480	" {10} So the king took his signet ring from his finger and gave it to Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of the Jews. {11} The king said to Haman,"
EST	3	11	Xerxes	#17		17481	" << Keep the money, and do with the people as you please.>>"
EST	3	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17482	 {12} Then on the thirteenth day of the first month the royal secretaries were summoned. 
EST	3	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17483	" They wrote out in the script of each province and in the language of each people all Haman's orders to the king's satraps, the governors of the various provinces and the nobles of the various peoples. "
EST	3	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17484	 These were written in the name of King Xerxes himself and sealed with his own ring.
EST	3	13	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17485	" {13} Dispatches were sent by couriers to all the king's provinces with the order to destroy, kill and annihilate all the Jews--"
EST	3	13	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17486	" young and old, women and little children--on a single day, the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the month of Adar, and to plunder their goods."
EST	3	14	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17487	 {14} A copy of the text of the edict was to be issued as law in every province and made known to the people of every nationality so they would be ready for that day.
EST	3	15	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17488	" {15} Spurred on by the king's command, the couriers went out, and the edict was issued in the citadel of Susa. "
EST	3	15	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17489	" The king and Haman sat down to drink, but the city of Susa was bewildered.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
EST	4	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17490	ESTHER 4
EST	4	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17491	" {1} When Mordecai learned of all that had been done, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and went out into the city, wailing loudly and bitterly."
EST	4	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17492	" {2} But he went only as far as the king's gate, because no one clothed in sackcloth was allowed to enter it."
EST	4	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17493	" {3} In every province to which the edict and order of the king came, there was great mourning among the Jews, with fasting, weeping and wailing. Many lay in sackcloth and ashes."
EST	4	4	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17494	" {4} When Esther's maids and eunuchs came and told her about Mordecai, she was in great distress. She sent clothes for him to put on instead of his sackcloth, but he would not accept them."
EST	4	5	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17495	" {5} Then Esther summoned Hathach, one of the king's eunuchs assigned to attend her, and ordered him to find out what was troubling Mordecai and why."
EST	4	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17496	 {6} So Hathach went out to Mordecai in the open square of the city in front of the king's gate. When Mordecai learned of all that had be
EST	4	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17497	" {7} Mordecai told him everything that had happened to him, including the exact amount of money Haman had promised to pay into the royal treasury for the destruction of the Jews."
EST	4	8	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17498	" {8} He also gave him a copy of the text of the edict for their annihilation, which had been published in Susa, to show to Esther and explain it to her, "
EST	4	8	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17499	 and he told him to urge her to go into the king's presence to beg for mercy and plead with him for her people.
EST	4	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17500	" {9} Hathach went back and reported to Esther what Mordecai had said. {10} Then she instructed him to say to Mordecai,"
EST	4	11	Esther (female)	#23		17501	 {11} << All the king's officials and the people of the royal provinces know that for any man or woman who approaches the king in the inner court without being summoned the king has but one law: that he be put to death. 
EST	4	11	Esther (female)	#23		17502	 The only exception to this is for the king to extend the gold scepter to him and spare his life. But thirty days have passed since I was called to go to the king.>>
EST	4	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17503	" {12} When Esther's words were reported to Mordecai, {13} he sent back this answer:"
EST	4	13	Mordecai	#01		17504	 << Do not think that because you are in the king's house you alone of all the Jews will escape.
EST	4	14	Mordecai	#01		17505	" {14} For if you remain silent at this time, relief and deliverance for the Jews will arise from another place, but you and your father's family will perish. "
EST	4	14	Mordecai	#01		17506	 And who knows but that you have come to royal position for such a time as this?>>
EST	4	15	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17507	 {15} Then Esther sent this reply to Mordecai:
EST	4	16	Esther (female)	#23		17508	" {16} << Go, gather together all the Jews who are in Susa, and fast for me. Do not eat or drink for three days, night or day. "
EST	4	16	Esther (female)	#23		17509	" I and my maids will fast as you do. When this is done, I will go to the king, even though it is against the law. And if I perish, I perish.>>"
EST	4	17	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17510	 {17} So Mordecai went away and carried out all of Esther's instructions.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
EST	5	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17511	ESTHER 5
EST	5	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17512	" {1} On the third day Esther put on her royal robes and stood in the inner court of the palace, in front of the king's hall. The king was sitting on his royal throne in the hall, facing the entrance."
EST	5	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17513	" {2} When he saw Queen Esther standing in the court, he was pleased with her and held out to her the gold scepter that was in his hand. So Esther approached and touched the tip of the scepter."
EST	5	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17514	" {3} Then the king asked,"
EST	5	3	Xerxes	#17		17515	" << What is it, Queen Esther? What is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be given you.>>"
EST	5	4	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17516	" {4} Esther said,"
EST	5	4	Esther (female)	#23		17517	" << If it pleases the king, let the king, together with Haman, come today to a banquet I have prepared for him.>>"
EST	5	5	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17518	" {5} Xerxes replied,"
EST	5	5	Xerxes	#17		17519	" << Bring Haman at once, so that we may do what Esther asks.>>"
EST	5	5	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17520	" So the king and Haman went to the banquet Esther had prepared. {6} As they were drinking wine, the king again asked Esther,"
EST	5	6	Xerxes	#17		17521	" << Now what is your petition? It will be given you. And what is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be granted.>>"
EST	5	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17522	" {7} Esther replied,"
EST	5	7	Esther (female)	#23		17523	 << My petition and my request is this:
EST	5	8	Esther (female)	#23		17524	" {8} If the king regards me with favor and if it pleases the king to grant my petition and fulfill my request, let the king and Haman come tomorrow to the banquet I will prepare for them. "
EST	5	8	Esther (female)	#23		17525	 Then I will answer the king's question.>>
EST	5	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17526	 {9} Haman went out that day happy and in high spirits. 
EST	5	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17527	" But when he saw Mordecai at the king's gate and observed that he neither rose nor showed fear in his presence, he was filled with rage against Mordecai."
EST	5	10	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17528	" {10} Nevertheless, Haman restrained himself and went home. Calling together his friends and Zeresh, his wife,"
EST	5	11	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17529	" {11} Haman boasted to them about his vast wealth, his many sons, and all the ways the king had honored him and how he had elevated him above the other nobles and officials."
EST	5	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17530	" {12} Haman added,"
EST	5	12	Haman	#11		17531	 << And that's not all. I'm the only person Queen Esther invited to accompany the king to the banquet she gave. And she has invited me along with the king tomorrow.
EST	5	13	Haman	#11		17532	 {13} But all this gives me no satisfaction as long as I see that Jew Mordecai sitting at the king's gate.>>
EST	5	14	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17533	" {14} His wife Zeresh and all his friends said to him,"
EST	5	14	Wife of Haman	#22		17534	" << Have a gallows built, seventy-five feet high, and ask the king in the morning to have Mordecai hanged on it. Then go with the king to the dinner and be happy.>>"
EST	5	14	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17535	" This suggestion delighted Haman, and he had the gallows built.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
EST	6	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17536	ESTHER 6
EST	6	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17537	" {1} That night the king could not sleep; so he ordered the book of the chronicles, the record of his reign, to be brought in and read to him."
EST	6	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17538	" {2} It was found recorded there that Mordecai had exposed Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king's officers who guarded the doorway, who had conspired to assassinate King Xerxes."
EST	6	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17539	" {3} The king asked,"
EST	6	3	Xerxes	#17		17540	 << What honor and recognition has Mordecai received for this?>>
EST	6	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17541	" His attendants answered,"
EST	6	3	Servant	#16		17542	 << Nothing has been done for him.>>
EST	6	4	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17543	" {4} The king said,"
EST	6	4	Xerxes	#17		17544	 << Who is in the court?>>
EST	6	4	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17545	" Now Haman had just entered the outer court of the palace to speak to the king about hanging Mordecai on the gallows he had erected for him. {5} His attendants answered,"
EST	6	5	Servant	#16		17546	 << Haman is standing in the court.>>
EST	6	5	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17547	" The King ordered,"
EST	6	5	Xerxes	#17		17548	 << Bring him in.>>
EST	6	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17549	" {6} When Haman entered, the king asked him,"
EST	6	6	Xerxes	#17		17550	 << What should be done for the man the king delights to honor?>>
EST	6	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17551	" Now Haman thought to himself,"
EST	6	6	Haman	#11		17552	 << Who is there that the king would rather honor than me?>>
EST	6	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17553	" {7} So he answered the king,"
EST	6	7	Haman	#11		17554	" << For the man the king delights to honor, {8} have them bring a royal robe the king has worn and a horse the king has ridden, one with a royal crest placed on its head."
EST	6	9	Haman	#11		17555	 {9} Then let the robe and horse be entrusted to one of the king's most noble princes.
EST	6	9	Haman	#11		17556	" Let them robe the man the king delights to honor, and lead him on the horse through the city streets, proclaiming before him, 'This is what is done for the man the king delights to honor!'>>"
EST	6	10	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17557	" {10} The king commanded Haman,"
EST	6	10	Xerxes	#17		17558	" << Go at once! Get the robe and the horse and do just as you have suggested for Mordecai the Jew, who sits at the king's gate. Do not neglect anything you have recommended.>>"
EST	6	11	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17559	" {11} So Haman got the robe and the horse. He robed Mordecai, and led him on horseback through the city streets, proclaiming before him,"
EST	6	11	Haman	#11		17560	" << This is what is done for the man the king delights to honor! This is what is done for the man the king delights to honor,"
EST	6	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17561	" {12} Afterward Mordecai returned to the king's gate. But Haman rushed home, with his head covered in grief,"
EST	6	13	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17562	" {13} and told Zeresh his wife and all his friends everything that had happened to him. His advisers and his wife Zeresh said to him,"
EST	6	13	Wife of Haman	#22		17563	" << Since Mordecai, before whom your downfall has started, is of Jewish origin, you cannot stand against him. You will surely come to ruin!>>"
EST	6	14	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17564	" {14} While they were still talking with him, the king's eunuchs arrived and hurried Haman away to the banquet Esther had prepared.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
EST	7	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17565	ESTHER 7
EST	7	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17566	" {1} So the king and Haman went to dine with Queen Esther, {2} and as they were drinking wine on that second day, the king again asked,"
EST	7	2	Xerxes	#17		17567	" << Queen Esther, what is your petition? It will be given you. What is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be granted.>>"
EST	7	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17568	" {3} Then Queen Esther answered,"
EST	7	3	Esther (female)	#23		17569	" << If I have found favor with you, O king, and if it pleases your majesty, grant me my life--this is my petition. And spare my people--this is my request."
EST	7	4	Esther (female)	#23		17570	 {4} For I and my people have been sold for destruction and slaughter and annihilation. 
EST	7	4	Esther (female)	#23		17571	" If we had merely been sold as male and female slaves, I would have kept quiet, because no such distress would justify disturbing the king.>>"
EST	7	5	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17572	" {5} King Xerxes asked Queen Esther,"
EST	7	5	Xerxes	#17		17573	 << Who is he? Where is the man who has dared to do such a thing?>>
EST	7	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17574	" {6} Queen Esther said,"
EST	7	6	Esther (female)	#23		17575	 << The adversary and enemy is this vile Haman.>>
EST	7	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17576	 Then Haman was terrified before the king and queen.
EST	7	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17577	" {7} The king got up in a rage, left his wine and went out into the palace garden. But Haman, realizing that the king had already decided his fate, stayed behind to beg Queen Esther for his life."
EST	7	8	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17578	" {8} Just as the king returned from the palace garden to the banquet hall, Haman was falling on the couch where Esther was reclining. The king exclaimed,"
EST	7	8	Xerxes	#17		17579	 << Will he even molest the queen while she is with me in the house?>>
EST	7	8	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17580	" As soon as the word left the king's mouth, they covered Haman's face. {9} Then Harbona, one of the eunuchs attending the king, said,"
EST	7	9	Eunuch	#09		17581	" << A gallows seventy-five feet high stands by Haman's house. He had it made for Mordecai, who spoke up to help the king.>>"
EST	7	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17582	" The King said,"
EST	7	9	Xerxes	#17		17583	 << Hang him on it!>>
EST	7	10	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17584	 {10} So they hanged Haman on the gallows he had prepared for Mordecai. Then the king's fury subsided.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
EST	8	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17585	ESTHER 8
EST	8	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17586	" {1} That same day King Xerxes gave Queen Esther the estate of Haman, the enemy of the Jews. And Mordecai came into the presence of the king, for Esther had told how he was related to her."
EST	8	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17587	" {2} The king took off his signet ring, which he had reclaimed from Haman, and presented it to Mordecai. And Esther appointed him over Haman's estate."
EST	8	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17588	" {3} Esther again pleaded with the king, falling at his feet and weeping. She begged him to put an end to the evil plan of Haman the Agagite, which he had devised against the Jews."
EST	8	4	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17589	" {4} Then the king extended the gold scepter to Esther and she arose and stood before him. {5} She said,"
EST	8	5	Esther (female)	#23		17590	" << If it pleases the king, and if he regards me with favor and thinks it the right thing to do, and if he is pleased with me,"
EST	8	5	Esther (female)	#23		17591	" let an order be written overruling the dispatches that Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, devised and wrote to destroy the Jews in all the king's provinces."
EST	8	6	Esther (female)	#23		17592	 {6} For how can I bear to see disaster fall on my people? How can I bear to see the destruction of my family?>>
EST	8	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17593	" {7} King Xerxes replied to Queen Esther and to Mordecai the Jew,"
EST	8	7	Xerxes	#17		17594	" << Because Haman attacked the Jews, I have given his estate to Esther, and they have hanged him on the gallows."
EST	8	8	Xerxes	#17		17595	" {8} Now write another decree in the king's name in behalf of the Jews as seems best to you, and seal it with the king's signet ring--for no document written in the king's name and sealed with his ring can be revoked.>>"
EST	8	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17596	" {9} At once the royal secretaries were summoned--on the twenty-third day of the third month, the month of Sivan. "
EST	8	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17597	" They wrote out all Mordecai's orders to the Jews, and to the satraps, governors and nobles of the 127 provinces stretching from India to Cush. "
EST	8	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17598	 These orders were written in the script of each province and the language of each people and also to the Jews in their own script and language.
EST	8	10	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17599	" {10} Mordecai wrote in the name of King Xerxes, sealed the dispatches with the king's signet ring, and sent them by mounted couriers, who rode fast horses especially bred for the king."
EST	8	11	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17600	 {11} The king's edict granted the Jews in every city the right to assemble and protect themselves;
EST	8	11	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17601	" to destroy, kill and annihilate any armed force of any nationality or province that might attack them and their women and children; and to plunder the property of their enemies."
EST	8	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17602	" {12} The day appointed for the Jews to do this in all the provinces of King Xerxes was the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the month of Adar."
EST	8	13	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17603	 {13} A copy of the text of the edict was to be issued as law in every province and made known to the people of every nationality so that the Jews would be ready on that day to avenge themselves on their enemies.
EST	8	14	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17604	" {14} The couriers, riding the royal horses, raced out, spurred on by the king's command. And the edict was also issued in the citadel of Susa."
EST	8	15	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17605	" {15} Mordecai left the king's presence wearing royal garments of blue and white, a large crown of gold and a purple robe of fine linen. And the city of Susa held a joyous celebration."
EST	8	16	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17606	" {16} For the Jews it was a time of happiness and joy, gladness and honor."
EST	8	17	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17607	" {17} In every province and in every city, wherever the edict of the king went, there was joy and gladness among the Jews, with feasting and celebrating. "
EST	8	17	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17608	 And many people of other nationalities became Jews because fear of the Jews had seized them.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
EST	9	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17609	ESTHER 9
EST	9	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17610	" {1} On the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, the month of Adar, the edict commanded by the king was to be carried out. "
EST	9	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17611	" On this day the enemies of the Jews had hoped to overpower them, but now the tables were turned and the Jews got the upper hand over those who hated them."
EST	9	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17612	 {2} The Jews assembled in their cities in all the provinces of King Xerxes to attack those seeking their destruction. 
EST	9	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17613	" No one could stand against them, because the people of all the other nationalities were afraid of them."
EST	9	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17614	" {3} And all the nobles of the provinces, the satraps, the governors and the king's administrators helped the Jews, because fear of Mordecai had seized them."
EST	9	4	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17615	" {4} Mordecai was prominent in the palace; his reputation spread throughout the provinces, and he became more and more powerful."
EST	9	5	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17616	" {5} The Jews struck down all their enemies with the sword, killing and destroying them, and they did what they pleased to those who hated them."
EST	9	6	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17617	" {6} In the citadel of Susa, the Jews killed and destroyed five hundred men."
EST	9	7	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17618	" {7} They also killed Parshandatha, Dalphon, Aspatha, {8} Poratha, Adalia, Aridatha,"
EST	9	9	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17619	" {9} Parmashta, Arisai, Aridai and Vaizatha,"
EST	9	10	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17620	" {10} the ten sons of Haman son of Hammedatha, the enemy of the Jews. But they did not lay their hands on the plunder."
EST	9	11	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17621	 {11} The number of those slain in the citadel of Susa was reported to the king that same day.
EST	9	12	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17622	" {12} The king said to Queen Esther,"
EST	9	12	Xerxes	#17		17623	 << The Jews have killed and destroyed five hundred men and the ten sons of Haman in the citadel of Susa. 
EST	9	12	Xerxes	#17		17624	 What have they done in the rest of the king's provinces? Now what is your petition? It will be given you. What is your request? It will also be granted.>>
EST	9	13	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17625	" {13} Esther answered,"
EST	9	13	Esther (female)	#23		17626	" << If it pleases the king, give the Jews in Susa permission to carry out this day's edict tomorrow also, and let Haman's ten sons be hanged on gallows.>>"
EST	9	14	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17627	" {14} So the king commanded that this be done. An edict was issued in Susa, and they hanged the ten sons of Haman."
EST	9	15	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17628	" {15} The Jews in Susa came together on the fourteenth day of the month of Adar, and they put to death in Susa three hundred men, but they did not lay their hands on the plunder."
EST	9	16	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17629	" {16} Meanwhile, the remainder of the Jews who were in the king's provinces also assembled to protect themselves and get relief from their enemies. "
EST	9	16	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17630	 They killed seventy-five thousand of them but did not lay their hands on the plunder.
EST	9	17	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17631	" {17} This happened on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar, and on the fourteenth they rested and made it a day of feasting and joy."
EST	9	18	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17632	" {18} The Jews in Susa, however, had assembled on the thirteenth and fourteenth, and then on the fifteenth they rested and made it a day of feasting and joy."
EST	9	19	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17633	" {19} That is why rural Jews--those living in villages--observe the fourteenth of the month of Adar as a day of joy and feasting, a day for giving presents to each other."
EST	9	20	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17634	" {20} Mordecai recorded these events, and he sent letters to all the Jews throughout the provinces of King Xerxes, near and far,"
EST	9	21	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17635	 {21} to have them celebrate annually the fourteenth and fifteenth days of the month of Adar
EST	9	22	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17636	" {22} as the time when the Jews got relief from their enemies, and as the month when their sorrow was turned into joy and their mourning into a day of celebration. "
EST	9	22	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17637	 He wrote them to observe the days as days of feasting and joy and giving presents of food to one another and gifts to the poor.
EST	9	23	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17638	" {23} So the Jews agreed to continue the celebration they had begun, doing what Mordecai had written to them."
EST	9	24	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17639	" {24} For Haman son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews, had plotted against the Jews to destroy them and had cast the pur (that is, the lot) for their ruin and destruction."
EST	9	25	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17640	" {25} But when the plot came to the king's attention, he issued written orders that the evil scheme Haman had devised against the Jews should come back onto his own head, and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows."
EST	9	26	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17641	" {26} (Therefore these days were called Purim, from the word pur.) Because of everything written in this letter and because of what they had seen and what had happened to them,"
EST	9	27	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17642	" {27} the Jews took it upon themselves to establish the custom that they and their descendants and all who join them should without fail observe these two days every year, in the way prescribed and at the time appointed."
EST	9	28	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17643	" {28} These days should be remembered and observed in every generation by every family, and in every province and in every city. "
EST	9	28	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17644	" And these days of Purim should never cease to be celebrated by the Jews, nor should the memory of them die out among their descendants."
EST	9	29	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17645	" {29} So Queen Esther, daughter of Abihail, along with Mordecai the Jew, wrote with full authority to confirm this second letter concerning Purim."
EST	9	30	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17646	 {30} And Mordecai sent letters to all the Jews in the 127 provinces of the kingdom of Xerxes --words of goodwill and assurance--
EST	9	31	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17647	" {31} to establish these days of Purim at their designated times, as Mordecai the Jew and Queen Esther had decreed for them, and as they had established for themselves and their descendants in regard to their times of fasting and lamentation."
EST	9	32	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17648	" {32} Esther's decree confirmed these regulations about Purim, and it was written down in the records.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
EST	10	<<	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17649	ESTHER 10
EST	10	1	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17650	" {1} King Xerxes imposed tribute throughout the empire, to its distant shores."
EST	10	2	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17651	" {2} And all his acts of power and might, together with a full account of the greatness of Mordecai to which the king had raised him, are they not written in the book of the annals of the kings of Media and Persia?"
EST	10	3	Narr_17: Esther	#25		17652	" {3} Mordecai the Jew was second in rank to King Xerxes, preeminent among the Jews, and held in high esteem by his many fellow Jews, because he worked for the good of his people and spoke up for the welfare of all the Jews.*~**~*||||| + 5 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	1	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17653	JOB*~*JOB 1
JOB	1	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17654	 {1} In the land of Uz there lived a man whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright; he feared God and shunned evil.
JOB	1	2	Narr_18: Job	#13		17655	" {2} He had seven sons and three daughters,"
JOB	1	3	Narr_18: Job	#13		17656	" {3} and he owned seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen and five hundred donkeys, and had a large number of servants. "
JOB	1	3	Narr_18: Job	#13		17657	 He was the greatest man among all the people of the East.
JOB	1	4	Narr_18: Job	#13		17658	" {4} His sons used to take turns holding feasts in their homes, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them."
JOB	1	5	Narr_18: Job	#13		17659	" {5} When a period of feasting had run its course, Job would send and have them purified. Early in the morning he would sacrifice a burnt offering for each of them, thinking,"
JOB	1	5	Job	#01		17660	 << Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.>>
JOB	1	5	Narr_18: Job	#13		17661	 This was Job's regular custom.
JOB	1	6	Narr_18: Job	#13		17662	" {6} One day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them. {7} The Lord said to Satan,"
JOB	1	7	God-FX1	#20		17663	 << Where have you come from?>>
JOB	1	7	Narr_18: Job	#13		17664	" Satan answered the Lord,"
JOB	1	7	Satan-FX1	#08		17665	 << From roaming through the earth and going back and forth in it.>>
JOB	1	8	Narr_18: Job	#13		17666	" {8} Then the Lord said to Satan,"
JOB	1	8	God-FX1	#20		17667	" << Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil.>>"
JOB	1	9	Narr_18: Job	#13		17668	" {9} Satan replied,"
JOB	1	9	Satan-FX1	#08		17669	 << Does Job fear God for nothing?
JOB	1	10	Satan-FX1	#08		17670	 {10} Have you not put a hedge around him and his household and everything he has? 
JOB	1	10	Satan-FX1	#08		17671	" You have blessed the work of his hands, so that his flocks and herds are spread throughout the land."
JOB	1	11	Satan-FX1	#08		17672	" {11} But stretch out your hand and strike everything he has, and he will surely curse you to your face.>>"
JOB	1	12	Narr_18: Job	#13		17673	" {12} The Lord said to Satan,"
JOB	1	12	God-FX1	#20		17674	" << Very well, then, everything he has is in your hands, but on the man himself do not lay a finger.>>"
JOB	1	12	Narr_18: Job	#13		17675	 Then Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.
JOB	1	13	Narr_18: Job	#13		17676	" {13} One day when Job's sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother's house, {14} a messenger came to Job and said,"
JOB	1	14	Messenger #1	#03		17677	" << The oxen were plowing and the donkeys were grazing nearby, {15} and the Sabeans attacked and carried them off. "
JOB	1	15	Messenger #1	#03		17678	" They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!>>"
JOB	1	16	Narr_18: Job	#13		17679	" {16} While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said,"
JOB	1	16	Messenger #2	#16		17680	" << The fire of God fell from the sky and burned up the sheep and the servants, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!>>"
JOB	1	17	Narr_18: Job	#13		17681	" {17} While he was still speaking, another messenger came and said,"
JOB	1	17	Messenger #3	#14		17682	 << The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and swept down on your camels and carried them off. 
JOB	1	17	Messenger #3	#14		17683	" They put the servants to the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!>>"
JOB	1	18	Narr_18: Job	#13		17684	" {18} While he was still speaking, yet another messenger came and said,"
JOB	1	18	Messenger #4	#12		17685	" << Your sons and daughters were feasting and drinking wine at the oldest brother's house,"
JOB	1	19	Messenger #4	#12		17686	 {19} when suddenly a mighty wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house.
JOB	1	19	Messenger #4	#12		17687	" It collapsed on them and they are dead, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!>>"
JOB	1	20	Narr_18: Job	#13		17688	" {20} At this, Job got up and tore his robe and shaved his head. Then he fell to the ground in worship {21} and said:"
JOB	1	21	Job	#01		17689	" << Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked I will depart. The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away; may the name of the Lord be praised.>>"
JOB	1	22	Narr_18: Job	#13		17690	" {22} In all this, Job did not sin by charging God with wrongdoing.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	2	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17691	JOB 2
JOB	2	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17692	" {1} On another day the angels came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them to present himself before him. {2} And the Lord said to Satan,"
JOB	2	2	God-FX1	#20		17693	 << Where have you come from?>>
JOB	2	2	Narr_18: Job	#13		17694	" Satan answered the Lord,"
JOB	2	2	Satan-FX1	#08		17695	 << From roaming through the earth and going back and forth in it.>>
JOB	2	3	Narr_18: Job	#13		17696	" {3} Then the Lord said to Satan,"
JOB	2	3	God-FX1	#20		17697	" << Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one on earth like him; he is blameless and upright, a man who fears God and shuns evil. "
JOB	2	3	God-FX1	#20		17698	" And he still maintains his integrity, though you incited me against him to ruin him without any reason.>>"
JOB	2	4	Narr_18: Job	#13		17699	" {4} Satan replied,"
JOB	2	4	Satan-FX1	#08		17700	 << Skin for skin! A man will give all he has for his own life.
JOB	2	5	Satan-FX1	#08		17701	" {5} But stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face.>>"
JOB	2	6	Narr_18: Job	#13		17702	" {6} The Lord said to Satan,"
JOB	2	6	God-FX1	#20		17703	" << Very well, then, he is in your hands; but you must spare his life.>>"
JOB	2	7	Narr_18: Job	#13		17704	 {7} So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord and afflicted Job with painful sores from the soles of his feet to the top of his head.
JOB	2	8	Narr_18: Job	#13		17705	" {8} Then Job took a piece of broken pottery and scraped himself with it as he sat among the ashes. {9} His wife said to him,"
JOB	2	9	Wife of Job	#22		17706	 << Are you still holding on to your integrity? Curse God and die!>>
JOB	2	10	Narr_18: Job	#13		17707	" {10} He replied,"
JOB	2	10	God-FX1	#20		17708	" << You are talking like a foolish woman. Shall we accept good from God, and not trouble?>>"
JOB	2	10	Narr_18: Job	#13		17709	" In all this, Job did not sin in what he said."
JOB	2	11	Narr_18: Job	#13		17710	" {11} When Job's three friends, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite, heard about all the troubles that had come upon him, "
JOB	2	11	Narr_18: Job	#13		17711	 they set out from their homes and met together by agreement to go and sympathize with him and comfort him.
JOB	2	12	Narr_18: Job	#13		17712	" {12} When they saw him from a distance, they could hardly recognize him; they began to weep aloud, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads."
JOB	2	13	Narr_18: Job	#13		17713	" {13} Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights. No one said a word to him, because they saw how great his suffering was.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	3	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17714	JOB 3
JOB	3	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17715	" {1} After this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth. {2} He said:"
JOB	3	3	Job	#01		17716	" {3} << May the day of my birth perish, and the night it was said, 'A boy is born!'"
JOB	3	4	Job	#01		17717	 {4} That day--may it turn to darkness; may God above not care about it; may no light shine upon it.
JOB	3	5	Job	#01		17718	 {5} May darkness and deep shadow claim it once more; may a cloud settle over it; may blackness overwhelm its light.
JOB	3	6	Job	#01		17719	 {6} That night--may thick darkness seize it; may it not be included among the days of the year nor be entered in any of the months.
JOB	3	7	Job	#01		17720	" {7} May that night be barren; may no shout of joy be heard in it. {8} May those who curse days curse that day, those who are ready to rouse Leviathan."
JOB	3	9	Job	#01		17721	" {9} May its morning stars become dark; may it wait for daylight in vain and not see the first rays of dawn, {10} for it did not shut the doors of the womb on me to hide trouble from my eyes."
JOB	3	11	Job	#01		17722	" {11} << Why did I not perish at birth, and die as I came from the womb? {12} Why were there knees to receive me and breasts that I might be nursed?"
JOB	3	13	Job	#01		17723	" {13} For now I would be lying down in peace; I would be asleep and at rest {14} with kings and counselors of the earth, who built for themselves places now lying in ruins,"
JOB	3	15	Job	#01		17724	" {15} with rulers who had gold, who filled their houses with silver."
JOB	3	16	Job	#01		17725	" {16} Or why was I not hidden in the ground like a stillborn child, like an infant who never saw the light of day?"
JOB	3	17	Job	#01		17726	" {17} There the wicked cease from turmoil, and there the weary are at rest. {18} Captives also enjoy their ease; they no longer hear the slave driver's shout."
JOB	3	19	Job	#01		17727	" {19} The small and the great are there, and the slave is freed from his master."
JOB	3	20	Job	#01		17728	" {20} << Why is light given to those in misery, and life to the bitter of soul,"
JOB	3	21	Job	#01		17729	" {21} to those who long for death that does not come, who search for it more than for hidden treasure,"
JOB	3	22	Job	#01		17730	 {22} who are filled with gladness and rejoice when they reach the grave?
JOB	3	23	Job	#01		17731	" {23} Why is life given to a man whose way is hidden, whom God has hedged in? {24} For sighing comes to me instead of food; my groans pour out like water."
JOB	3	25	Job	#01		17732	 {25} What I feared has come upon me; what I dreaded has happened to me.
JOB	3	26	Job	#01		17733	" {26} I have no peace, no quietness; I have no rest, but only turmoil.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	4	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17734	JOB 4
JOB	4	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17735	 {1} Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
JOB	4	2	Eliphaz	#11		17736	" {2} << If someone ventures a word with you, will you be impatient? But who can keep from speaking?"
JOB	4	3	Eliphaz	#11		17737	" {3} Think how you have instructed many, how you have strengthened feeble hands."
JOB	4	4	Eliphaz	#11		17738	 {4} Your words have supported those who stumbled; you have strengthened faltering knees.
JOB	4	5	Eliphaz	#11		17739	" {5} But now trouble comes to you, and you are discouraged; it strikes you, and you are dismayed."
JOB	4	6	Eliphaz	#11		17740	 {6} Should not your piety be your confidence and your blameless ways your hope?
JOB	4	7	Eliphaz	#11		17741	" {7} << Consider now: Who, being innocent, has ever perished? Where were the upright ever destroyed?"
JOB	4	8	Eliphaz	#11		17742	" {8} As I have observed, those who plow evil and those who sow trouble reap it."
JOB	4	9	Eliphaz	#11		17743	 {9} At the breath of God they are destroyed; at the blast of his anger they perish.
JOB	4	10	Eliphaz	#11		17744	" {10} The lions may roar and growl, yet the teeth of the great lions are broken."
JOB	4	11	Eliphaz	#11		17745	" {11} The lion perishes for lack of prey, and the cubs of the lioness are scattered."
JOB	4	12	Eliphaz	#11		17746	" {12} << A word was secretly brought to me, my ears caught a whisper of it."
JOB	4	13	Eliphaz	#11		17747	" {13} Amid disquieting dreams in the night, when deep sleep falls on men, {14} fear and trembling seized me and made all my bones shake."
JOB	4	15	Eliphaz	#11		17748	" {15} A spirit glided past my face, and the hair on my body stood on end."
JOB	4	16	Eliphaz	#11		17749	" {16} It stopped, but I could not tell what it was. A form stood before my eyes, and I heard a hushed voice:"
JOB	4	17	Eliphaz	#11		17750	 {17} 'Can a mortal be more righteous than God? Can a man be more pure than his Maker?
JOB	4	18	Eliphaz	#11		17751	" {18} If God places no trust in his servants, if he charges his angels with error,"
JOB	4	19	Eliphaz	#11		17752	" {19} how much more those who live in houses of clay, whose foundations are in the dust, who are crushed more readily than a moth!"
JOB	4	20	Eliphaz	#11		17753	" {20} Between dawn and dusk they are broken to pieces; unnoticed, they perish forever."
JOB	4	21	Eliphaz	#11		17754	" {21} Are not the cords of their tent pulled up, so that they die without wisdom?*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	5	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17755	JOB 5
JOB	5	1	Eliphaz	#11		17756	" {1} << Call if you will, but who will answer you? To which of the holy ones will you turn?"
JOB	5	2	Eliphaz	#11		17757	" {2} Resentment kills a fool, and envy slays the simple. {3} I myself have seen a fool taking root, but suddenly his house was cursed."
JOB	5	4	Eliphaz	#11		17758	" {4} His children are far from safety, crushed in court without a defender."
JOB	5	5	Eliphaz	#11		17759	" {5} The hungry consume his harvest, taking it even from among thorns, and the thirsty pant after his wealth."
JOB	5	6	Eliphaz	#11		17760	" {6} For hardship does not spring from the soil, nor does trouble sprout from the ground."
JOB	5	7	Eliphaz	#11		17761	 {7} Yet man is born to trouble as surely as sparks fly upward.
JOB	5	8	Eliphaz	#11		17762	" {8} << But if it were I, I would appeal to God; I would lay my cause before him."
JOB	5	9	Eliphaz	#11		17763	" {9} He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted."
JOB	5	10	Eliphaz	#11		17764	 {10} He bestows rain on the earth; he sends water upon the countryside.
JOB	5	11	Eliphaz	#11		17765	" {11} The lowly he sets on high, and those who mourn are lifted to safety."
JOB	5	12	Eliphaz	#11		17766	" {12} He thwarts the plans of the crafty, so that their hands achieve no success."
JOB	5	13	Eliphaz	#11		17767	" {13} He catches the wise in their craftiness, and the schemes of the wily are swept away."
JOB	5	14	Eliphaz	#11		17768	 {14} Darkness comes upon them in the daytime; at noon they grope as in the night.
JOB	5	15	Eliphaz	#11		17769	 {15} He saves the needy from the sword in their mouth; he saves them from the clutches of the powerful.
JOB	5	16	Eliphaz	#11		17770	" {16} So the poor have hope, and injustice shuts its mouth."
JOB	5	17	Eliphaz	#11		17771	 {17} << Blessed is the man whom God corrects; so do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
JOB	5	18	Eliphaz	#11		17772	" {18} For he wounds, but he also binds up; he injures, but his hands also heal."
JOB	5	19	Eliphaz	#11		17773	 {19} From six calamities he will rescue you; in seven no harm will befall you.
JOB	5	20	Eliphaz	#11		17774	" {20} In famine he will ransom you from death, and in battle from the stroke of the sword."
JOB	5	21	Eliphaz	#11		17775	" {21} You will be protected from the lash of the tongue, and need not fear when destruction comes."
JOB	5	22	Eliphaz	#11		17776	" {22} You will laugh at destruction and famine, and need not fear the beasts of the earth."
JOB	5	23	Eliphaz	#11		17777	" {23} For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field, and the wild animals will be at peace with you."
JOB	5	24	Eliphaz	#11		17778	 {24} You will know that your tent is secure; you will take stock of your property and find nothing missing.
JOB	5	25	Eliphaz	#11		17779	" {25} You will know that your children will be many, and your descendants like the grass of the earth."
JOB	5	26	Eliphaz	#11		17780	" {26} You will come to the grave in full vigor, like sheaves gathered in season."
JOB	5	27	Eliphaz	#11		17781	" {27} << We have examined this, and it is true. So hear it and apply it to yourself.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	6	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17782	JOB 6
JOB	6	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17783	 {1} Then Job replied:
JOB	6	2	Job	#01		17784	 {2} << If only my anguish could be weighed and all my misery be placed on the scales!
JOB	6	3	Job	#01		17785	 {3} It would surely outweigh the sand of the seas-- no wonder my words have been impetuous.
JOB	6	4	Job	#01		17786	" {4} The arrows of the Almighty are in me, my spirit drinks in their poison; God's terrors are marshaled against me."
JOB	6	5	Job	#01		17787	" {5} Does a wild donkey bray when it has grass, or an ox bellow when it has fodder?"
JOB	6	6	Job	#01		17788	" {6} Is tasteless food eaten without salt, or is there flavor in the white of an egg? {7} I refuse to touch it; such food makes me ill."
JOB	6	8	Job	#01		17789	" {8} << Oh, that I might have my request, that God would grant what I hope for,"
JOB	6	9	Job	#01		17790	" {9} that God would be willing to crush me, to let loose his hand and cut me off!"
JOB	6	10	Job	#01		17791	 {10} Then I would still have this consolation-- my joy in unrelenting pain-- that I had not denied the words of the Holy One.
JOB	6	11	Job	#01		17792	" {11} << What strength do I have, that I should still hope? What prospects, that I should be patient?"
JOB	6	12	Job	#01		17793	" {12} Do I have the strength of stone? Is my flesh bronze? {13} Do I have any power to help myself, now that success has been driven from me?"
JOB	6	14	Job	#01		17794	" {14} << A despairing man should have the devotion of his friends, even though he forsakes the fear of the Almighty."
JOB	6	15	Job	#01		17795	" {15} But my brothers are as undependable as intermittent streams, as the streams that overflow {16} when darkened by thawing ice and swollen with melting snow,"
JOB	6	17	Job	#01		17796	" {17} but that cease to flow in the dry season, and in the heat vanish from their channels."
JOB	6	18	Job	#01		17797	 {18} Caravans turn aside from their routes; they go up into the wasteland and perish.
JOB	6	19	Job	#01		17798	" {19} The caravans of Tema look for water, the traveling merchants of Sheba look in hope."
JOB	6	20	Job	#01		17799	" {20} They are distressed, because they had been confident; they arrive there, only to be disappointed."
JOB	6	21	Job	#01		17800	 {21} Now you too have proved to be of no help; you see something dreadful and are afraid.
JOB	6	22	Job	#01		17801	" {22} Have I ever said, 'Give something on my behalf, pay a ransom for me from your wealth,"
JOB	6	23	Job	#01		17802	" {23} deliver me from the hand of the enemy, ransom me from the clutches of the ruthless'?"
JOB	6	24	Job	#01		17803	" {24} << Teach me, and I will be quiet; show me where I have been wrong. {25} How painful are honest words! But what do your arguments prove?"
JOB	6	26	Job	#01		17804	" {26} Do you mean to correct what I say, and treat the words of a despairing man as wind?"
JOB	6	27	Job	#01		17805	 {27} You would even cast lots for the fatherless and barter away your friend.
JOB	6	28	Job	#01		17806	 {28} << But now be so kind as to look at me. Would I lie to your face?
JOB	6	29	Job	#01		17807	" {29} Relent, do not be unjust; reconsider, for my integrity is at stake."
JOB	6	30	Job	#01		17808	 {30} Is there any wickedness on my lips? Can my mouth not discern malice?*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
JOB	7	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17809	JOB 7
JOB	7	1	Job	#01		17810	 {1} << Does not man have hard service on earth? Are not his days like those of a hired man?
JOB	7	2	Job	#01		17811	" {2} Like a slave longing for the evening shadows, or a hired man waiting eagerly for his wages,"
JOB	7	3	Job	#01		17812	" {3} so I have been allotted months of futility, and nights of misery have been assigned to me."
JOB	7	4	Job	#01		17813	" {4} When I lie down I think, 'How long before I get up?' The night drags on, and I toss till dawn. {5} My body is clothed with worms and scabs, my skin is broken and festering."
JOB	7	6	Job	#01		17814	" {6} << My days are swifter than a weaver's shuttle, and they come to an end without hope."
JOB	7	7	Job	#01		17815	" {7} Remember, O God, that my life is but a breath; my eyes will never see happiness again."
JOB	7	8	Job	#01		17816	" {8} The eye that now sees me will see me no longer; you will look for me, but I will be no more."
JOB	7	9	Job	#01		17817	" {9} As a cloud vanishes and is gone, so he who goes down to the grave does not return."
JOB	7	10	Job	#01		17818	 {10} He will never come to his house again; his place will know him no more.
JOB	7	11	Job	#01		17819	" {11} << Therefore I will not keep silent; I will speak out in the anguish of my spirit, I will complain in the bitterness of my soul."
JOB	7	12	Job	#01		17820	" {12} Am I the sea, or the monster of the deep, that you put me under guard?"
JOB	7	13	Job	#01		17821	" {13} When I think my bed will comfort me and my couch will ease my complaint,"
JOB	7	14	Job	#01		17822	" {14} even then you frighten me with dreams and terrify me with visions,"
JOB	7	15	Job	#01		17823	" {15} so that I prefer strangling and death, rather than this body of mine."
JOB	7	16	Job	#01		17824	 {16} I despise my life; I would not live forever. Let me alone; my days have no meaning.
JOB	7	17	Job	#01		17825	" {17} << What is man that you make so much of him, that you give him so much attention, {18} that you examine him every morning and test him every moment?"
JOB	7	19	Job	#01		17826	" {19} Will you never look away from me, or let me alone even for an instant?"
JOB	7	20	Job	#01		17827	" {20} If I have sinned, what have I done to you, O watcher of men? Why have you made me your target? Have I become a burden to you?"
JOB	7	21	Job	#01		17828	" {21} Why do you not pardon my offenses and forgive my sins? For I will soon lie down in the dust; you will search for me, but I will be no more.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	8	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17829	JOB 8
JOB	8	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17830	 {1} Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
JOB	8	2	Bildad	#02		17831	 {2} <<How long will you say such things? Your words are a blustering wind.
JOB	8	3	Bildad	#02		17832	 {3} Does God pervert justice? Does the Almighty pervert what is right?
JOB	8	4	Bildad	#02		17833	" {4} When your children sinned against him, he gave them over to the penalty of their sin."
JOB	8	5	Bildad	#02		17834	" {5} But if you will look to God and plead with the Almighty, {6} if you are pure and upright, even now he will rouse himself on your behalf and restore you to your rightful place."
JOB	8	7	Bildad	#02		17835	" {7} Your beginnings will seem humble, so prosperous will your future be."
JOB	8	8	Bildad	#02		17836	" {8} << Ask the former generations and find out what their fathers learned, {9} for we were born only yesterday and know nothing, and our days on earth are but a shadow."
JOB	8	10	Bildad	#02		17837	 {10} Will they not instruct you and tell you? Will they not bring forth words from their understanding?
JOB	8	11	Bildad	#02		17838	" {11} Can papyrus grow tall where there is no marsh? Can reeds thrive without water? {12} While still growing and uncut, they wither more quickly than grass."
JOB	8	13	Bildad	#02		17839	 {13} Such is the destiny of all who forget God; so perishes the hope of the godless.
JOB	8	14	Bildad	#02		17840	 {14} What he trusts in is fragile; what he relies on is a spider's web.
JOB	8	15	Bildad	#02		17841	" {15} He leans on his web, but it gives way; he clings to it, but it does not hold."
JOB	8	16	Bildad	#02		17842	" {16} He is like a well-watered plant in the sunshine, spreading its shoots over the garden;"
JOB	8	17	Bildad	#02		17843	 {17} it entwines its roots around a pile of rocks and looks for a place among the stones.
JOB	8	18	Bildad	#02		17844	" {18} But when it is torn from its spot, that place disowns it and says, 'I never saw you.'"
JOB	8	19	Bildad	#02		17845	" {19} Surely its life withers away, and from the soil other plants grow."
JOB	8	20	Bildad	#02		17846	 {20} << Surely God does not reject a blameless man or strengthen the hands of evildoers.
JOB	8	21	Bildad	#02		17847	 {21} He will yet fill your mouth with laughter and your lips with shouts of joy.
JOB	8	22	Bildad	#02		17848	" {22} Your enemies will be clothed in shame, and the tents of the wicked will be no more.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	9	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17849	JOB 9
JOB	9	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17850	" {1} Then Job replied,"
JOB	9	2	Job	#01		17851	" {2} << Indeed, I know that this is true. But how can a mortal be righteous before God?"
JOB	9	3	Job	#01		17852	" {3} Though one wished to dispute with him, he could not answer him one time out of a thousand."
JOB	9	4	Job	#01		17853	" {4} His wisdom is profound, his power is vast. Who has resisted him and come out unscathed?"
JOB	9	5	Job	#01		17854	 {5} He moves mountains without their knowing it and overturns them in his anger. {6} He shakes the earth from its place and makes its pillars tremble.
JOB	9	7	Job	#01		17855	 {7} He speaks to the sun and it does not shine; he seals off the light of the stars.
JOB	9	8	Job	#01		17856	 {8} He alone stretches out the heavens and treads on the waves of the sea.
JOB	9	9	Job	#01		17857	" {9} He is the Maker of the Bear and Orion, the Pleiades and the constellations of the south."
JOB	9	10	Job	#01		17858	" {10} He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted."
JOB	9	11	Job	#01		17859	" {11} When he passes me, I cannot see him; when he goes by, I cannot perceive him."
JOB	9	12	Job	#01		17860	" {12} If he snatches away, who can stop him? Who can say to him, 'What are you doing?'"
JOB	9	13	Job	#01		17861	 {13} God does not restrain his anger; even the cohorts of Rahab cowered at his feet.
JOB	9	14	Job	#01		17862	 {14} << How then can I dispute with him? How can I find words to argue with him?
JOB	9	15	Job	#01		17863	" {15} Though I were innocent, I could not answer him; I could only plead with my Judge for mercy."
JOB	9	16	Job	#01		17864	" {16} Even if I summoned him and he responded, I do not believe he would give me a hearing."
JOB	9	17	Job	#01		17865	 {17} He would crush me with a storm and multiply my wounds for no reason. {18} He would not let me regain my breath but would overwhelm me with misery.
JOB	9	19	Job	#01		17866	" {19} If it is a matter of strength, he is mighty! And if it is a matter of justice, who will summon him?"
JOB	9	20	Job	#01		17867	" {20} Even if I were innocent, my mouth would condemn me; if I were blameless, it would pronounce me guilty."
JOB	9	21	Job	#01		17868	" {21} << Although I am blameless, I have no concern for myself; I despise my own life."
JOB	9	22	Job	#01		17869	" {22} It is all the same; that is why I say, 'He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.'"
JOB	9	23	Job	#01		17870	" {23} When a scourge brings sudden death, he mocks the despair of the innocent."
JOB	9	24	Job	#01		17871	" {24} When a land falls into the hands of the wicked, he blindfolds its judges. If it is not he, then who is it?"
JOB	9	25	Job	#01		17872	 {25} << My days are swifter than a runner; they fly away without a glimpse of joy.
JOB	9	26	Job	#01		17873	" {26} They skim past like boats of papyrus, like eagles swooping down on their prey."
JOB	9	27	Job	#01		17874	" {27} If I say, 'I will forget my complaint, I will change my expression, and smile,'"
JOB	9	28	Job	#01		17875	" {28} I still dread all my sufferings, for I know you will not hold me innocent. {29} Since I am already found guilty, why should I struggle in vain?"
JOB	9	30	Job	#01		17876	" {30} Even if I washed myself with soap and my hands with washing soda, {31} you would plunge me into a slime pit so that even my clothes would detest me."
JOB	9	32	Job	#01		17877	" {32} << He is not a man like me that I might answer him, that we might confront each other in court."
JOB	9	33	Job	#01		17878	" {33} If only there were someone to arbitrate between us, to lay his hand upon us both,"
JOB	9	34	Job	#01		17879	" {34} someone to remove God's rod from me, so that his terror would frighten me no more."
JOB	9	35	Job	#01		17880	" {35} Then I would speak up without fear of him, but as it now stands with me, I cannot.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	10	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17881	JOB 10
JOB	10	1	Job	#01		17882	 {1} << I loathe my very life; therefore I will give free rein to my complaint and speak out in the bitterness of my soul.
JOB	10	2	Job	#01		17883	" {2} I will say to God: Do not condemn me, but tell me what charges you have against me."
JOB	10	3	Job	#01		17884	" {3} Does it please you to oppress me, to spurn the work of your hands, while you smile on the schemes of the wicked?"
JOB	10	4	Job	#01		17885	 {4} Do you have eyes of flesh? Do you see as a mortal sees?
JOB	10	5	Job	#01		17886	" {5} Are your days like those of a mortal or your years like those of a man, {6} that you must search out my faults and probe after my sin--"
JOB	10	7	Job	#01		17887	 {7} though you know that I am not guilty and that no one can rescue me from your hand?
JOB	10	8	Job	#01		17888	 {8} << Your hands shaped me and made me. Will you now turn and destroy me?
JOB	10	9	Job	#01		17889	 {9} Remember that you molded me like clay. Will you now turn me to dust again?
JOB	10	10	Job	#01		17890	" {10} Did you not pour me out like milk and curdle me like cheese, {11} clothe me with skin and flesh and knit me together with bones and sinews?"
JOB	10	12	Job	#01		17891	" {12} You gave me life and showed me kindness, and in your providence watched over my spirit."
JOB	10	13	Job	#01		17892	" {13} << But this is what you concealed in your heart, and I know that this was in your mind:"
JOB	10	14	Job	#01		17893	" {14} If I sinned, you would be watching me and would not let my offense go unpunished."
JOB	10	15	Job	#01		17894	" {15} If I am guilty--woe to me! Even if I am innocent, I cannot lift my head, for I am full of shame and drowned in my affliction."
JOB	10	16	Job	#01		17895	" {16} If I hold my head high, you stalk me like a lion and again display your awesome power against me."
JOB	10	17	Job	#01		17896	 {17} You bring new witnesses against me and increase your anger toward me; your forces come against me wave upon wave.
JOB	10	18	Job	#01		17897	 {18} << Why then did you bring me out of the womb? I wish I had died before any eye saw me.
JOB	10	19	Job	#01		17898	" {19} If only I had never come into being, or had been carried straight from the womb to the grave!"
JOB	10	20	Job	#01		17899	" {20} Are not my few days almost over? Turn away from me so I can have a moment's joy {21} before I go to the place of no return, to the land of gloom and deep shadow,"
JOB	10	22	Job	#01		17900	" {22} to the land of deepest night, of deep shadow and disorder, where even the light is like darkness.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	11	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17901	JOB 11
JOB	11	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17902	 {1} Then Zophar the Naamathite replied:
JOB	11	2	Zophar	#15		17903	 {2} << Are all these words to go unanswered? Is this talker to be vindicated?
JOB	11	3	Zophar	#15		17904	 {3} Will your idle talk reduce men to silence? Will no one rebuke you when you mock?
JOB	11	4	Zophar	#15		17905	" {4} You say to God, 'My beliefs are flawless and I am pure in your sight.'"
JOB	11	5	Zophar	#15		17906	" {5} Oh, how I wish that God would speak, that he would open his lips against you"
JOB	11	6	Zophar	#15		17907	" {6} and disclose to you the secrets of wisdom, for true wisdom has two sides. Know this: God has even forgotten some of your sin."
JOB	11	7	Zophar	#15		17908	 {7} << Can you fathom the mysteries of God? Can you probe the limits of the Almighty?
JOB	11	8	Zophar	#15		17909	 {8} They are higher than the heavens--what can you do? They are deeper than the depths of the grave--what can you know?
JOB	11	9	Zophar	#15		17910	 {9} Their measure is longer than the earth and wider than the sea.
JOB	11	10	Zophar	#15		17911	" {10} << If he comes along and confines you in prison and convenes a court, who can oppose him?"
JOB	11	11	Zophar	#15		17912	" {11} Surely he recognizes deceitful men; and when he sees evil, does he not take note?"
JOB	11	12	Zophar	#15		17913	 {12} But a witless man can no more become wise than a wild donkey's colt can be born a man.
JOB	11	13	Zophar	#15		17914	" {13} << Yet if you devote your heart to him and stretch out your hands to him,"
JOB	11	14	Zophar	#15		17915	" {14} if you put away the sin that is in your hand and allow no evil to dwell in your tent,"
JOB	11	15	Zophar	#15		17916	 {15} then you will lift up your face without shame; you will stand firm and without fear.
JOB	11	16	Zophar	#15		17917	" {16} You will surely forget your trouble, recalling it only as waters gone by."
JOB	11	17	Zophar	#15		17918	" {17} Life will be brighter than noonday, and darkness will become like morning."
JOB	11	18	Zophar	#15		17919	" {18} You will be secure, because there is hope; you will look about you and take your rest in safety."
JOB	11	19	Zophar	#15		17920	" {19} You will lie down, with no one to make you afraid, and many will court your favor."
JOB	11	20	Zophar	#15		17921	" {20} But the eyes of the wicked will fail, and escape will elude them; their hope will become a dying gasp.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	12	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17922	JOB 12
JOB	12	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17923	" {1} Then Job replied,"
JOB	12	2	Job	#01		17924	" {2} << Doubtless you are the people, and wisdom will die with you!"
JOB	12	3	Job	#01		17925	 {3} But I have a mind as well as you; I am not inferior to you. Who does not know all these things?
JOB	12	4	Job	#01		17926	" {4} << I have become a laughingstock to my friends, though I called upon God and he answered-- a mere laughingstock, though righteous and blameless!"
JOB	12	5	Job	#01		17927	 {5} Men at ease have contempt for misfortune as the fate of those whose feet are slipping.
JOB	12	6	Job	#01		17928	" {6} The tents of marauders are undisturbed, and those who provoke God are secure-- those who carry their god in their hands."
JOB	12	7	Job	#01		17929	" {7} << But ask the animals, and they will teach you, or the birds of the air, and they will tell you;"
JOB	12	8	Job	#01		17930	" {8} or speak to the earth, and it will teach you, or let the fish of the sea inform you."
JOB	12	9	Job	#01		17931	 {9} Which of all these does not know that the hand of the Lord has done this?
JOB	12	10	Job	#01		17932	 {10} In his hand is the life of every creature and the breath of all mankind. {11} Does not the ear test words as the tongue tastes food?
JOB	12	12	Job	#01		17933	 {12} Is not wisdom found among the aged? Does not long life bring understanding?
JOB	12	13	Job	#01		17934	 {13} << To God belong wisdom and power; counsel and understanding are his.
JOB	12	14	Job	#01		17935	 {14} What he tears down cannot be rebuilt; the man he imprisons cannot be released.
JOB	12	15	Job	#01		17936	" {15} If he holds back the waters, there is drought; if he lets them loose, they devastate the land."
JOB	12	16	Job	#01		17937	 {16} To him belong strength and victory; both deceived and deceiver are his. {17} He leads counselors away stripped and makes fools of judges.
JOB	12	18	Job	#01		17938	 {18} He takes off the shackles put on by kings and ties a loincloth around their waist.
JOB	12	19	Job	#01		17939	 {19} He leads priests away stripped and overthrows men long established.
JOB	12	20	Job	#01		17940	 {20} He silences the lips of trusted advisers and takes away the discernment of elders. {21} He pours contempt on nobles and disarms the mighty.
JOB	12	22	Job	#01		17941	 {22} He reveals the deep things of darkness and brings deep shadows into the light.
JOB	12	23	Job	#01		17942	" {23} He makes nations great, and destroys them; he enlarges nations, and disperses them."
JOB	12	24	Job	#01		17943	 {24} He deprives the leaders of the earth of their reason; he sends them wandering through a trackless waste.
JOB	12	25	Job	#01		17944	 {25} They grope in darkness with no light; he makes them stagger like drunkards.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
JOB	13	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17945	JOB 13
JOB	13	1	Job	#01		17946	" {1} <<My eyes have seen all this, my ears have heard and understood it. {2} What you know, I also know; I am not inferior to you."
JOB	13	3	Job	#01		17947	" {3} But I desire to speak to the Almighty and to argue my case with God. {4} You, however, smear me with lies; you are worthless physicians, all of you!"
JOB	13	5	Job	#01		17948	" {5} If only you would be altogether silent! For you, that would be wisdom. {6} Hear now my argument; listen to the plea of my lips."
JOB	13	7	Job	#01		17949	 {7} Will you speak wickedly on God's behalf? Will you speak deceitfully for him? {8} Will you show him partiality? Will you argue the case for God?
JOB	13	9	Job	#01		17950	 {9} Would it turn out well if he examined you? Could you deceive him as you might deceive men?
JOB	13	10	Job	#01		17951	 {10} He would surely rebuke you if you secretly showed partiality. {11} Would not his splendor terrify you? Would not the dread of him fall on you?
JOB	13	12	Job	#01		17952	 {12} Your maxims are proverbs of ashes; your defenses are defenses of clay.
JOB	13	13	Job	#01		17953	 {13} << Keep silent and let me speak; then let come to me what may. {14} Why do I put myself in jeopardy and take my life in my hands?
JOB	13	15	Job	#01		17954	" {15} Though he slay me, yet will I hope in him; I will surely defend my ways to his face."
JOB	13	16	Job	#01		17955	" {16} Indeed, this will turn out for my deliverance, for no godless man would dare come before him!"
JOB	13	17	Job	#01		17956	" {17} Listen carefully to my words; let your ears take in what I say. {18} Now that I have prepared my case, I know I will be vindicated."
JOB	13	19	Job	#01		17957	" {19} Can anyone bring charges against me? If so, I will be silent and die."
JOB	13	20	Job	#01		17958	" {20} << Only grant me these two things, O God, and then I will not hide from you:"
JOB	13	21	Job	#01		17959	" {21} Withdraw your hand far from me, and stop frightening me with your terrors."
JOB	13	22	Job	#01		17960	" {22} Then summon me and I will answer, or let me speak, and you reply."
JOB	13	23	Job	#01		17961	 {23} How many wrongs and sins have I committed? Show me my offense and my sin. {24} Why do you hide your face and consider me your enemy?
JOB	13	25	Job	#01		17962	 {25} Will you torment a windblown leaf? Will you chase after dry chaff?
JOB	13	26	Job	#01		17963	 {26} For you write down bitter things against me and make me inherit the sins of my youth.
JOB	13	27	Job	#01		17964	 {27} You fasten my feet in shackles; you keep close watch on all my paths by putting marks on the soles of my feet.
JOB	13	28	Job	#01		17965	" {28} << So man wastes away like something rotten, like a garment eaten by moths.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*"
JOB	14	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17966	JOB 14
JOB	14	1	Job	#01		17967	" {1} <<Man born of woman is of few days and full of trouble. {2} He springs up like a flower and withers away; like a fleeting shadow, he does not endure."
JOB	14	3	Job	#01		17968	 {3} Do you fix your eye on such a one? Will you bring him before you for judgment? {4} Who can bring what is pure from the impure? No one!
JOB	14	5	Job	#01		17969	 {5} Man's days are determined; you have decreed the number of his months and have set limits he cannot exceed.
JOB	14	6	Job	#01		17970	" {6} So look away from him and let him alone, till he has put in his time like a hired man."
JOB	14	7	Job	#01		17971	" {7} << At least there is hope for a tree: If it is cut down, it will sprout again, and its new shoots will not fail."
JOB	14	8	Job	#01		17972	" {8} Its roots may grow old in the ground and its stump die in the soil, {9} yet at the scent of water it will bud and put forth shoots like a plant."
JOB	14	10	Job	#01		17973	 {10} But man dies and is laid low; he breathes his last and is no more.
JOB	14	11	Job	#01		17974	" {11} As water disappears from the sea or a riverbed becomes parched and dry,"
JOB	14	12	Job	#01		17975	" {12} so man lies down and does not rise; till the heavens are no more, men will not awake or be roused from their sleep."
JOB	14	13	Job	#01		17976	 {13} << If only you would hide me in the grave and conceal me till your anger has passed! If only you would set me a time and then remember me!
JOB	14	14	Job	#01		17977	" {14} If a man dies, will he live again? All the days of my hard service I will wait for my renewal to come."
JOB	14	15	Job	#01		17978	 {15} You will call and I will answer you; you will long for the creature your hands have made.
JOB	14	16	Job	#01		17979	 {16} Surely then you will count my steps but not keep track of my sin. {17} My offenses will be sealed up in a bag; you will cover over my sin.
JOB	14	18	Job	#01		17980	" {18} << But as a mountain erodes and crumbles and as a rock is moved from its place,"
JOB	14	19	Job	#01		17981	" {19} as water wears away stones and torrents wash away the soil, so you destroy man's hope."
JOB	14	20	Job	#01		17982	" {20} You overpower him once for all, and he is gone; you change his countenance and send him away."
JOB	14	21	Job	#01		17983	" {21} If his sons are honored, he does not know it; if they are brought low, he does not see it."
JOB	14	22	Job	#01		17984	 {22} He feels but the pain of his own body and mourns only for himself.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
JOB	15	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		17985	JOB 15
JOB	15	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		17986	 {1} Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:
JOB	15	2	Eliphaz	#11		17987	 {2} <<Would a wise man answer with empty notions or fill his belly with the hot east wind?
JOB	15	3	Eliphaz	#11		17988	" {3} Would he argue with useless words, with speeches that have no value?"
JOB	15	4	Eliphaz	#11		17989	 {4} But you even undermine piety and hinder devotion to God.
JOB	15	5	Eliphaz	#11		17990	 {5} Your sin prompts your mouth; you adopt the tongue of the crafty.
JOB	15	6	Eliphaz	#11		17991	" {6} Your own mouth condemns you, not mine; your own lips testify against you."
JOB	15	7	Eliphaz	#11		17992	 {7} << Are you the first man ever born? Were you brought forth before the hills?
JOB	15	8	Eliphaz	#11		17993	 {8} Do you listen in on God's council? Do you limit wisdom to yourself?
JOB	15	9	Eliphaz	#11		17994	 {9} What do you know that we do not know? What insights do you have that we do not have?
JOB	15	10	Eliphaz	#11		17995	" {10} The gray-haired and the aged are on our side, men even older than your father."
JOB	15	11	Eliphaz	#11		17996	" {11} Are God's consolations not enough for you, words spoken gently to you?"
JOB	15	12	Eliphaz	#11		17997	" {12} Why has your heart carried you away, and why do your eyes flash, {13} so that you vent your rage against God and pour out such words from your mouth?"
JOB	15	14	Eliphaz	#11		17998	" {14} << What is man, that he could be pure, or one born of woman, that he could be righteous?"
JOB	15	15	Eliphaz	#11		17999	" {15} If God places no trust in his holy ones, if even the heavens are not pure in his eyes, {16} how much less man, who is vile and corrupt, who drinks up evil like water!"
JOB	15	17	Eliphaz	#11		18000	" {17} << Listen to me and I will explain to you; let me tell you what I have seen,"
JOB	15	18	Eliphaz	#11		18001	" {18} what wise men have declared, hiding nothing received from their fathers"
JOB	15	19	Eliphaz	#11		18002	 {19} (to whom alone the land was given when no alien passed among them):
JOB	15	20	Eliphaz	#11		18003	" {20} All his days the wicked man suffers torment, the ruthless through all the years stored up for him."
JOB	15	21	Eliphaz	#11		18004	" {21} Terrifying sounds fill his ears; when all seems well, marauders attack him."
JOB	15	22	Eliphaz	#11		18005	 {22} He despairs of escaping the darkness; he is marked for the sword.
JOB	15	23	Eliphaz	#11		18006	 {23} He wanders about--food for vultures; he knows the day of darkness is at hand.
JOB	15	24	Eliphaz	#11		18007	" {24} Distress and anguish fill him with terror; they overwhelm him, like a king poised to attack,"
JOB	15	25	Eliphaz	#11		18008	" {25} because he shakes his fist at God and vaunts himself against the Almighty, {26} defiantly charging against him with a thick, strong shield."
JOB	15	27	Eliphaz	#11		18009	" {27} << Though his face is covered with fat and his waist bulges with flesh, {28} he will inhabit ruined towns and houses where no one lives, houses crumbling to rubble."
JOB	15	29	Eliphaz	#11		18010	" {29} He will no longer be rich and his wealth will not endure, nor will his possessions spread over the land."
JOB	15	30	Eliphaz	#11		18011	" {30} He will not escape the darkness; a flame will wither his shoots, and the breath of God's mouth will carry him away."
JOB	15	31	Eliphaz	#11		18012	" {31} Let him not deceive himself by trusting what is worthless, for he will get nothing in return."
JOB	15	32	Eliphaz	#11		18013	" {32} Before his time he will be paid in full, and his branches will not flourish."
JOB	15	33	Eliphaz	#11		18014	" {33} He will be like a vine stripped of its unripe grapes, like an olive tree shedding its blossoms."
JOB	15	34	Eliphaz	#11		18015	" {34} For the company of the godless will be barren, and fire will consume the tents of those who love bribes."
JOB	15	35	Eliphaz	#11		18016	 {35} They conceive trouble and give birth to evil; their womb fashions deceit.>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
JOB	16	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		18017	JOB 16
JOB	16	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		18018	" {1} Then Job replied,"
JOB	16	2	Job	#01		18019	 {2} << I have heard many things like these; miserable comforters are you all!
JOB	16	3	Job	#01		18020	 {3} Will your long-winded speeches never end? What ails you that you keep on arguing?
JOB	16	4	Job	#01		18021	" {4} I also could speak like you, if you were in my place; I could make fine speeches against you and shake my head at you."
JOB	16	5	Job	#01		18022	 {5} But my mouth would encourage you; comfort from my lips would bring you relief.
JOB	16	6	Job	#01		18023	" {6} << Yet if I speak, my pain is not relieved; and if I refrain, it does not go away."
JOB	16	7	Job	#01		18024	" {7} Surely, O God, you have worn me out; you have devastated my entire household."
JOB	16	8	Job	#01		18025	 {8} You have bound me--and it has become a witness; my gauntness rises up and testifies against me.
JOB	16	9	Job	#01		18026	 {9} God assails me and tears me in his anger and gnashes his teeth at me; my opponent fastens on me his piercing eyes.
JOB	16	10	Job	#01		18027	 {10} Men open their mouths to jeer at me; they strike my cheek in scorn and unite together against me.
JOB	16	11	Job	#01		18028	 {11} God has turned me over to evil men and thrown me into the clutches of the wicked.
JOB	16	12	Job	#01		18029	" {12} All was well with me, but he shattered me; he seized me by the neck and crushed me. "
JOB	16	12	Job	#01		18030	" He has made me his target; {13} his archers surround me. Without pity, he pierces my kidneys and spills my gall on the ground."
JOB	16	14	Job	#01		18031	 {14} Again and again he bursts upon me; he rushes at me like a warrior.
JOB	16	15	Job	#01		18032	 {15} << I have sewed sackcloth over my skin and buried my brow in the dust.
JOB	16	16	Job	#01		18033	" {16} My face is red with weeping, deep shadows ring my eyes; {17} yet my hands have been free of violence and my prayer is pure."
JOB	16	18	Job	#01		18034	" {18} << O earth, do not cover my blood; may my cry never be laid to rest! {19} Even now my witness is in heaven; my advocate is on high."
JOB	16	20	Job	#01		18035	 {20} My intercessor is my friend as my eyes pour out tears to God; {21} on behalf of a man he pleads with God as a man pleads for his friend.
JOB	16	22	Job	#01		18036	 {22} << Only a few years will pass before I go on the journey of no return.*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
JOB	17	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		18037	JOB 17
JOB	17	1	Job	#01		18038	" {1} My spirit is broken, my days are cut short, the grave awaits me. {2} Surely mockers surround me; my eyes must dwell on their hostility."
JOB	17	3	Job	#01		18039	" {3} << Give me, O God, the pledge you demand. Who else will put up security for me?"
JOB	17	4	Job	#01		18040	 {4} You have closed their minds to understanding; therefore you will not let them triumph.
JOB	17	5	Job	#01		18041	" {5} If a man denounces his friends for reward, the eyes of his children will fail."
JOB	17	6	Job	#01		18042	" {6} << God has made me a byword to everyone, a man in whose face people spit."
JOB	17	7	Job	#01		18043	 {7} My eyes have grown dim with grief; my whole frame is but a shadow.
JOB	17	8	Job	#01		18044	 {8} Upright men are appalled at this; the innocent are aroused against the ungodly.
JOB	17	9	Job	#01		18045	" {9} Nevertheless, the righteous will hold to their ways, and those with clean hands will grow stronger."
JOB	17	10	Job	#01		18046	" {10} << But come on, all of you, try again! I will not find a wise man among you."
JOB	17	11	Job	#01		18047	" {11} My days have passed, my plans are shattered, and so are the desires of my heart."
JOB	17	12	Job	#01		18048	" {12} These men turn night into day; in the face of darkness they say, 'Light is near.'"
JOB	17	13	Job	#01		18049	" {13} If the only home I hope for is the grave, if I spread out my bed in darkness,"
JOB	17	14	Job	#01		18050	" {14} if I say to corruption, 'You are my father,' and to the worm, 'My mother' or 'My sister,' {15} where then is my hope? Who can see any hope for me?"
JOB	17	16	Job	#01		18051	 {16} Will it go down to the gates of death? Will we descend together into the dust?>>*~**~*||||| + 2 SECs |||||*~*
JOB	18	<<	Narr_18: Job	#13		18052	JOB 18
JOB	18	1	Narr_18: Job	#13		18053	 {1} Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:
JOB	18	2	Bildad	#02		18054	" {2} << When will you end these speeches? Be sensible, and then we can talk."
JOB	18	3	Bildad	#02		18055	 {3} Why are we regarded as cattle and considered stupid in your sight?
JOB	18	4	Bildad	#02		18056	" {4} You who tear yourself to pieces in your anger, is the earth to be abandoned for your sake? Or must the rocks be moved from their place?"
JOB	18	5	Bildad	#02		18057	 {5} << The lamp of the wicked is snuffed out; the flame of his fire stops burning.
JOB	18	6	Bildad	#02		18058	 {6} The light in his tent becomes dark; the lamp beside him goes out.
JOB	18	7	Bildad	#02		18059	 {7} The vigor of his step is weakened; his own schemes throw him down.
JOB	18	8	Bildad	#02		18060	 {8} His feet thrust him into a net and he wanders into its mesh.
JOB	18	9	Bildad	#02		18061	 {9} A trap seizes him by the heel; a snare holds him fast.
JOB	18	10	Bildad	#02		18062	 {10} A noose is hidden for him on the ground; a trap lies in his path.
JOB	18	11	Bildad	#02		18063	 {11} Terrors startle him on every side and dog his every step.
JOB	18	12	Bildad	#02		18064	 {12} Calamity is hungry for him; disaster is ready for him when he falls.
JOB	18	13	Bildad	#02		18065	 {13} It eats away parts of his skin; death's firstborn devours his limbs.
JOB	18	14	Bildad	#02		18066	 {14} He is torn from the security of his tent and marched off to the king of terrors.
JOB	18	15	Bildad	#02		18067	 {15} Fire resides in his tent; burning sulfur is scattered over his dwelling.
JOB	18	16	Bildad	#02		18068	 {16} His roots dry up below and his branches wither above.
JOB	18	17	Bildad	#02		18069	 {17} The memory of him perishes from the earth; he has no name in the land.
JOB	18	18	Bildad	#02		18070	 {18} He is driven from light into darkness and is banished from the world.
JOB	18	19	Bildad	#02		18071	" {19} He has no offspring or descendants among his people, no survivor where once he lived."
JOB	18	20	Bildad	#02		18072	 {20} Men of the west are appalled at his fate; men of the east are seized with horror.
